Award.AwardTitle: MOLECULAR DYNAMICS SIMULATIONS AND SMALL ANGLE NEUTRON SCATTERING STUDIES OF LIGHT- EMITTING POLYMERIC NANOPARTICLES
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Dvora Perahia of Clemson University will resolve the internal structure and dynamics of poly-dots, new soft nanoparticles, and probe their interaction with the environment. The research will provide a fundamental structural understanding of the factors that control the light emitting and absorbing properties of these particles through the combination of molecular dynamics simulations and neutron scattering methods. In the first stage, nanoparticles will be made from di-alkyl poly(paraphenylene ethynylene)s, and then the complexity of the nanoparticle will be increased by substituting the side chains of the polymer with various types of groups. The broader impacts of the research project include training graduate and undergraduate students in combined neutron scattering and computational methods, and engaging local high school students via a science club and directing them towards summer research experiences.

Plastics are long chain organic molecules and are found in many facets of everyday life, including food packaging, structural materials for automotive and aerospace transportation, and lightweight electronic devices. Electrically conducting carbon-based (organic) molecules and polymers hold enormous promise for realizing highly efficient, affordable, and broadly available electronic and optical devices. This research explores the molecular picture of a new type of very small conducting polymer particle, and resolves the effects of specific chemistries on the structure and behavior of the molecules that build these new materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Soft nanoparticles have an immense potential for medical diagnostics and therapeutics as targeted drug delivery vehicles and imaging/sensing probes.  These applications require a measurable readout such as fluorescent tags, radiolabeling, and target recognition groups, as well as means to carry a therapeutic cargo.  One emerging class of emissive materials consists of conjugated polymeric nanoparticles (NPs) with a soft core and cargo encapsulation ability. These are often referred to as polydots. To realize their full potential and move these NPs from a laboratory idea into use, their structure, stability and the motion have been studied using large-scale molecular dynamics simulations accompanied by neutron experimental techniques.  These studies resulted in numerous publications and presentations that describe a new understanding of the factors that control soft nanoparticles. This knowledge will significantly accelerate the transition of polydots from a fundamental idea to biotechnology.  In parallel, the efforts impact broader activities that have enhanced the accessibility of graduate students to computational tools in the US and across the world. 

The study focused on one family of polymers, di-substituted poly(paraphe­ny­lene­­ethynylene)s (PPEs).  The first phase of the research probed non-ionic PPEs followed by a second phase where the effects of ionic groups on structure and stability of the nanoparticle were studied.  The success of the project stems from our computational efforts, that together with insight from neutrons where able to resolve the structure and dynamics of polydots.   Underling the entire project has been our first success where we were able to develop a computational method to prepare the soft nanoparticles in a manner similar to the experimental procedures. Schematics of the procedure is shown in Figure 1. The polymer was placed in a cavity that was reduced in dimensions until reaching experimental densities and then transferred to solvents. This procedure marks as close as possible experimental-computational correlations that have enabled numerous additional studies.

Following preparation of the NPs, we could probe the structure and stability of a series of single molecule non-ionic polydots by neutron scattering and molecular dynamics simulations. We find that below the glass transition temperature of the polymers, polydots remain stable. With increasing temperature, they unravel, forming a cavity, as shown in Figure 2. This structure remains when quenched back below the glass transition temperature, enabling the encapsulation of cargo. (S. Maskey et al., Macromolecules 2016). Further, we were able to extract the motion of the backbone and correlated the time scale of this processes with photophysics observations.  

One fascinating class of conjugated polymer NPs are those that form organic inorganic hybrids. Here we were able to graft PPEs onto silica NPs and tune the chain conformation and assembly, as the solvent-polymer interactions were varied (S. Maskey et al., Langmuir 2016). An example of the different association is given in the cover of Langmuir, shown in Figure 3.  In this study, we not only resolved the assembly of NP confined chains, but we were also able to derive for the first time a method that allowed the characterization of correlations of chains grafted to inorganic NPs.

The second phase of the research have probed the effects of charge on the formation of polydots and their penetration pathways into membranes.  The study started with resolving for the first time the effects of charges on the conformation of carboxylated PPEs in solutions (S. Wijesinghe et al., Polymers, 2016); followed by understanding the effects of charges on the polydots (S. Wijesinghe et al., J. Chem. Phys, 2017).  We find that ionizable groups enhance significantly the thermal stability of the soft nanoparticles.

Small angle neutron studies have shown that dialkyl PPEs form well defined polydots (Figure 4).  The number of polymer molecules confined to one polydot depends on the initial concentration of the parent solution.   A shape transition from spherical to elliptical is observed in polydots that consist of more than one polymer molecule. The analysis however shows that the polydots are relatively polydispersed.  In conjunction with the computational, this work is currently summarized into two papers (N. Osti et al; S. Wijesinghe et. al).

We were able to follow computationally a polydot as it penetrates into a membrane as shown in Figure 5. (Wijesinghe et. al, in preparation).  In parallel, we were able to scale up our successful synthetic of ionizable PPEs to be able to derive PPEs with bio-compatible functionalities and form a polydot.

Broader impact activities resulted in multitude of educational initiatives that targeted graduate students.  Among them are a short course, organized by the PI together with Gary S. Grest on “Multiscale Computational Approaches for Simulating Polymers from Atomistic to Mesoscale”. This two day workshop brought together computational experts from around the world that delivered lectures to a large highly diverse group of graduate students.
